Construction of highly stable and efficient Zn-based catalyst via Mg modification for propane dehydrogenation Jie Zhang a 1 Tong Yu a 1 Junjie He a Jinwei Chen a b Gang Wang a b Zongbo Shi c Fuwen Yang a Junyu Zhao a Runsheng Zhuo a c Ruilin Wang a b ⁎ a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China College of Materials Science and Engineering Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 China aCollege of Materials Science and Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China b Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices, Ministry of Education, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China Engineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices Ministry of Education Sichuan University Chengdu 610065 China bEngineering Research Center of Alternative Energy Materials & Devices, Ministry of Education, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China c REZEL Catalysts Corporation, Shanghai 200120, China REZEL Catalysts Corporation Shanghai 200120 China cREZEL Catalysts Corporation, Shanghai 200120, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 J. Zhang and T. Yu contributed equally to this work. Zn-based catalysts are considered a kind of efficient catalysts for propane dehydrogenation (PDH) because of their low price and non-toxicity. However, Zn-based catalysts still face problems such as the limited diffusion of reaction gas, non-uniform distribution of Zn species, and easy coking. Here, a novel double-layered silicalite-1 (DS-1) support with high specific surface area was synthesized by a crystal growth method, and an alkaline additive modification strategy has been adopted to prepare the Mg-modified Zn-based catalyst (0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1) in order to improve the catalytic activity and stability. The physical characterization results reveal that the Mg modification induces the enhanced electronic interactions between Zn sites and Mg species. Besides, the modified Mg species also reduce the Lewis acidity, allowing easier desorption of propylene and improving the propylene selectivity with anti-coking property. Furthermore, PDH evaluation results demonstrate that the optimal 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst achieves the propylene yield of ∼44 %, propylene selectivity of ∼95 % as well as outstanding stability and regeneration ability. This work provides a novel insight into the design of Zn-based catalysts with high activity and excellent stability. Introduction Propylene, one of the key raw materials in the preparation of plastics, fibers, and intermediates for the chemical products, has brought about the derivation of on-demand propane dehydrogenation (PDH) technology [1]. Currently, Pt-based catalysts (such as Pt/BN [2], Pt/Fe-DMSN [3], and PtFe/SiO2 [4], etc.) and Cr-based catalysts (Cr/Al2O3 [5], CrOx/Zn-Al2O3 [6], and Cr2O3/Al2O3 [7], etc.) are commonly used commercial catalysts for industrial PDH. Nevertheless, the high toxicity and inferior stability of Cr and high-cost of Pt severely limit their wide application in chemical industry. Thus, developing cheap catalysts with efficient activity and robust stability is urgently required for PDH catalysis. At present, numerous investigations focus on exploring the Zn-based catalysts with high activity in catalyzing PDH process owing to their advantages of low cost and environmental friendliness [8]. Whereas, the high-temperature conditions during the PDH reaction might lead to the formation of inactive Zn phase and aggregation of Zn species [9]. Moreover, coke deposition usually results in the deactivation of Zn-based catalysts and leads to the rapid decrease on stability. Therefore, finding new strategies to boost the stability of Zn-based catalysts in propane dehydrogenation is still urgent but challenging. To enhance the activity and stability, modification of Zn-based catalysts with other metal elements have been proposed to enhance the structural stability of active sites in Zn-based catalysts. For instance, the trace Pt was introduced into ZnO catalysts, in which Pt acted as a promoter that could produce the stronger Lewis acid and restrain the coke deposition [10]. However, Pt resource is scarce and also shows high activity for PDH, which would hinder their commercialization and affect the predication of active sites. Fortunately, magnesium (Mg), an non-precious alkaline earth metal, could be widely used as a promoter in catalytic fields [11]. Wu et al. demonstrated that Mg in the Mg-modified VOx catalysts greatly contributed to the dispersion of V species, thereby reducing coke and increasing the stability of propane non-oxidative dehydrogenation [12]. Li et al. prepared Mg-incorporated SBA-15 with various Mg loadings and then employed the Mg-SBA-15 as support to load Pt and Sn species [11]. The modification on support not only improved the interaction between Sn and support, but also stabilized the oxidized Sn species, thereby resulting in an enhanced catalytic activity and stability. Recently, the introduction of Mg species into Zn-based catalysts has significantly improve the stability of PDH catalysts. For instance, the MgO-modified ZnOx/Silicalite-1 catalyst exhibited excellent activity, selectivity, and durability during PDH reaction [13]. The improvement can be attributed to the strong interactions between Mg2+ and ZnOx, thus stabilizing the Zn species and effectively inhibiting the Zn loss. However, the Mg-modified Zn-based catalysts are still rarely reported. The relevant enhancement mechanism of Mg o is not fully discussed, especially for improving the stability. Herein, a series of Mg-modified Zn-based catalysts were synthesized and employed for the direct propane dehydrogenation. Firstly, a novel double-layered silicalite-1 (DS-1) support with high specific surface area (SSA) was synthesized by the crystal growth method, and then the alkaline additive modification strategy has been adopted to prepare the Mg-modified Zn-based catalyst (Fig. 1 ). The results verified that the modification of Mg greatly improved the activity and stability of the Zn-based catalysts. The optimal 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst delivers ∼44 % of propylene yield, ∼95 % of propylene selectivity, and shows no significant deactivation for continuous reaction. The enhancement on PDH performance can be ascribed to the modification of Mg effectively promote the desorption of propylene, thus avoiding the deep dehydrogenation of propylene and the generation of coke on the catalyst. In addition, the essential reason for the improvement of catalytic performance caused by Mg modification was systematically discussed. This work offers a new way for improving the activity and stability of Zn-based catalysts in the field of alkane dehydrogenation. Experimental section Catalyst preparation Synthesis of S-1 9.4 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and 5.5 mL of aqueous tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) were dispersed in 20 mL of deionized water and continuously stirred at room temperature for 6 h. Then, the mixture solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and the reactor was heated at 170 °C for 48 h to subject the hydrothermal-static crystallization. After cooling to room temperature, the powder was obtained by centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times and then dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the product was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in a tubular furnace, which was named as S-1. Synthesis of DS-1 88 mg of S-1 was uniformly dispersed in 20 mL of deionized water and stirred overnight at room temperature. After that, 5.5 mL of TPAOH and 9.4 mL of TEOS were added into the mixed solution and hydrolyzed for 6 h. Then, the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor and heated at 170 ℃ for 48 h to finish the crystallization. After cooling down, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed for several times. Finally, the obtained product was calcined at 550 ℃ in air for 6 h to remove the template agent, which was named as DS-1. Synthesis of Mg-modified Zn-based catalyst 227 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 26 mg of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 80 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min. Then, 1 g of DS-1 was added into the above mixture solution, and then heated at 80 ℃ to completely remove the solvent. After that, the resulting powder was dried at 80 ℃ for 12 h and then calcined in air at 550 ℃ for 1 h to obtain the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst. As a comparison, 5Zn@DS-1 catalyst was synthesized with the identical procedure only without the addition of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O. Besides, 5Zn@S-1 was also synthesized by using the S-1 as support and without the addition of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O. Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα as the radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Thermo Fischer ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with monochromatic Al-Ka X-rays as the excitation source. The morphology of samples was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using FEI Inspect F50. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were collected on a 200 kV Talos F200S G2 (Thermo Fisher). Elemental distribution of catalyst was conducted under STEM mode using a Talos built-in energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) software. The Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the total specific surface area on Quantachrome Instruments (2SI-MP-20). Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used to analyze the pore size distribution. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected on a Bruker ALPHA Ⅱ spectrometer, recording against diffuse reflection, and the spectral range is from 4000 to 600 cm−1. Thermogravimetry (TG) was performed on TG 209 F1 (NETZSCH, Germany) from room temperature to 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 20 ℃ min−1. The Lewis and Brønsted acids of catalysts were analyzed by IR using a Tensor 27 spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) and pyridine was chosen as the probe molecule. NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) curves were obtained by an Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorption instrument (Mac Instruments, USA). Metal contents in catalysts were revealed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific iCAP PRO). Evaluation of catalyst performance Catalytic performance was conducted using a fixed bed equipped with stainless steel downflow reactor (14 mm inner diameter) operated at atmospheric pressure. Silica sand and quartz wool were placed below the catalyst to fix it at the constant temperature region of the fixed bed. Typically, 500 mg of catalyst was placed and fixed in the middle of stainless-steel reactor, then heated to 550 ℃ with nitrogen purge from room temperature. After that, it started to react at a total flow rate of 40 mL min−1 (5 % C3H8/95 % N2, volume ratios). The reaction products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The catalyst regeneration cycle was tested by sintering in air at 550 ℃ for 1 h. The propane conversion (Cpropane), propylene selectivity (Spropylene) and propylene yield (Ypropylene) were defined as follows: C p r o p a n e = n ˙ C 3 H 8 i n − n ˙ C 3 H 8 o u t n ˙ C 3 H 8 i n × 100 % S p r o p y l e n e = × 100 % Y p r o p y l e n e = n ˙ C 3 H 6 o u t n ˙ C 3 H 8 i n − n ˙ C 3 H 8 o u t n ˙ C 3 H 6 o u t n ˙ C 3 H 8 i n × 100 % Where n ˙ with superscripts ‘in’ or ‘out’ means the molar flow of gas phase components (mmol min−1). Results and discussion Morphology and structure of the catalysts Fig. 2 shows the XRD pattern of supports and the corresponding catalysts. Both S-1 and DS-1 possess the similar peaks with five distinct characteristic peaks of MFI structure at 7.9°, 8.8°, 23.1°, 23.9°, and 24.4°, revealing the typical MFI phase [14]. Compared with that of supports, the crystal structure of 5Zn@DS-1 and 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalysts could be well maintained with the addition of Mg and Zn species. Based on the ICP result (Table 1 ), Zn and Mg contents in 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 are 4.81 and 0.30 wt.%, respectively. In addition, no obvious diffraction peaks of ZnO or MgO were observed on the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1, which can be attributed to small particle sizes and the extremely low amounts of Zn and Mg species. In order to explore the dispersion of active Zn species, SEM images were used to reveal the morphological properties of supports. As shown in Fig. 3a -b, S-1 exhibit plate-like morphology of particles with the size of ∼160 nm. Moreover, DS-1 display a typical hexagonal structure with average size of ∼200 nm (Fig. 3c-d), which may be attributed to the second crystallization occurred on S-1 seed crystal that accelerated grain growth and obtained the double layer structure. Furthermore, it is essential to further explore the pore properties of DS-1 and its mass transfer mechanism. As shown in Fig. 4a and 4c, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of supports and catalysts show the typical type IV isotherm with an H-3 hysteresis loop, further demonstrating the existence of abundant mesopores [15]. Besides, the high N2 uptake at relative pressures (P/P0) < 0.02 was due to the micropore filling [16]. The pore size distributions (Fig. 4b ) show the hierarchical porosity of DS-1 including large amounts of mesopores (∼2.2 nm) and macropores (∼82 nm). As displayed in Table 2 , the BET SSA of DS-1 is calculated to be 444.69 m2 g−1, which is higher than that of S-1 (433.52 m2 g−1). Such a high SSA value is beneficial to exposing more active sites; meanwhile, the mesopores together with macropores are favorable for the access of reactant and desorption of product. It should be noted that the internal SSA of DS-1 decreased by ∼108 m2 g−1 when compared with S-1, further indicating the successfully generated epitaxial S-1 that covering a part of internal pores. In addition, the external specific surface area of DS-1 greatly increased due to the epitaxial S-1 shell with rough surface. In terms of 5Zn@DS-1 and 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1, both of Stotal and Sinternal dramatically decreased after loading with metal species in comparison to those of DS-1, implying that metal species mainly dispersed inside the pore channels of supports. In brief, the pore structure of DS-1 may allow more Zn species distribute inside the pore channels of the DS-1 and effectively promote the transport of propane and desorption of propylene, thus improving the reactivity and stability. The dispersion of metal species on the whole 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst was revealed by TEM. Fig. 5a displays the typical hexahedron MFI structure without obvious nanoparticles [17]. Fig. 5b further demonstrates that the Zn and Mg species were uniformly dispersed throughout the whole zeolite, which can be ascribed to the confinement of DS-1. Moreover, the particle size distribution of metal species reveals the average particle size of 3.66 nm without obvious metal agglomeration (Fig. 5c). Furthermore, EDS mapping images (Fig. 5d-i) reveal the uniform distribution of Mg, Zn, O, and Si elements on the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1. FTIR spectra of S-1 and DS-1 show the presence of isolated silanol groups (Si-OH) due to the peak appearing at ∼3400 cm–1 (Fig. 6a ). As shown in Fig. 6b, the decreased intensity of Si-OH on 5Zn@DS-1 and 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 might be associated with the reaction between OH and Zn species, revealing that abundant Si–OH facilitate to coordinate with Zn sites [18]. Moreover, the previous report indicated that Mg-doping participated in the formation of Zn-O-Mg bonds, which was verified by the shifted stretching vibration peak of Zn-O bond [19]. Compared with that of 5Zn@DS-1, the Zn-O bond of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 at ∼450 cm−1 shows no obvious shift, indicating Mg-doping does not change the vibration mode of Zn-O bond. Therefore, it can be speculated that the introduction of Mg does not form the MgO and Mg species exist in the form of isolated Mg2+ in the host structure. XPS characterizations were performed to confirm the compositions of 5Zn@DS-1 and 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1. XPS survey spectrum of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 confirms the element constitution of Mg, Zn, Si, and O (Fig. 7a ). As displayed in Fig. 7b, Zn peaks around 1045 eV and 1022 eV were assigned to Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2, respectively [20]. In terms of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1, the binding energy of Zn 2p negatively shifted ∼0.1 eV compared with that of 5Zn@DS-1. Besides, an additional Zn−O−Mg binding energy can be observed at ∼1017.6 eV (Fig. 7c), which results from the partial substitution of Zn2+ by Mg2+ [21]. More importantly, Mg atom incorporation induces a strong distortion of the interface layers and that its impact on the electronic structure of Zn species related to band-offset variations [22]. Generally, the observation of Mg 1 s should be accompanied by the Mg 2 s and Mg 2p. However, only Mg 1 s can be detected in the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1, which was ascribed to the ionization cross section (the chance of interaction with X-ray photons) of Mg 1 s is tens of times higher than that of Mg 2 s and Mg 2p. Meanwhile, the signal peaks of Mg 1 s was noisy due to the relatively low content of Mg. The Mg 1 s XPS spectrum (Fig. 7d) can be fitted into three peaks at 1306.7 eV, 1305.1 eV, and 1304.1 eV, further revealing the existence form of Mg2+ in 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 [17]. Compared with the standard binding energy of Mg2+ (1303.9 eV), the certain degree of positive shift occurred on 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 indicates that the Mg species lost electrons. The above XPS results demonstrate that the introduction of Mg induces the electronic interactions between Zn sites and Mg species as well as the gained electrons on Zn atoms. To verify the pivotal role of Mg on Lewis acidity of Zn species, IR spectroscopy was conducted at 150 °C by using pyridine as a probe molecule. As shown in Fig. 7e, the bands at 1600 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 are assigned to the hydrogen-bonded linked pyridine and the Lewis acid site of catalyst, respectively. Meanwhile, there is no band appeared at ∼1540 cm−1, indicating the absence of the Brønsted acid site on both 5Zn@DS-1 and 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1. More importantly, the bands locating at 1492 and 1610 cm−1 correspond to the stronger Lewis acid produced by Zn2+ active site [23]. The Lewis acidity of Zn2+ active site slightly decreased after modifying with Mg. According to Lewis acid-base theory, the weakened Lewis acidity allows more easily desorption of propylene and improves the propylene selectivity and anti-coking properties, thus further improving the stability [24]. Furthermore, the acidity changes on catalyst were analyzed using NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. 7f, the center of the desorption peak for 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 exhibits a shift toward the lower temperature, indicating that the modification of Mg caused a decrease on the acidity of the catalyst. The decreased acidic surface sites would weaken the adsorption strength of propane on catalyst and further reduce the generation of carbon accumulation [25]. As displayed in Fig. 8 , the Auger Zn LMM core level spectra can be divided into two kinetic energy peaks, corresponding to the different Zn species. The peaks located at ∼986 eV belong to the Zn2+ species that mainly in the form of framework O-bonded Zn with the higher electronegativity. Significantly, active Zn species with higher electronegativity may facilitate the desorption of propylene during PDH reaction, leading to a relative moderate side reaction [17]. The peaks at ∼989 eV on both of 5Zn@DS-1 and 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 can be ascribed to the ZnO formed on the supports [14]. Notably, the peak on 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 exhibits an obvious positive shift, indicating that the ZnO partially transformed to the ZnOx (0 < x < 1) with valence state of Znδ+ (0 < δ < 2) species owing to the gained electrons from Mg. To investigate the resistance to carbon accumulation, TG analysis was performed on the catalysts after 6 h of PDH reaction (Fig. 9a ). During the raised temperature from room temperature to 800 ℃, the mass loss of spent-5Zn@DS-1 and spent-0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 were 4.07 % and 0.15 %, respectively, indicating a significant reduction of coke on the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst. Significantly, after 6 h of PDH reaction, Zn species still possess uniform dispersion, which is beneficial to the continuous high-temperature reaction (Fig. 9b and Fig. 9c). The introduction of Mg modification with appropriate amount might contribute to the formation of highly dispersed Zn species due to the dilution role of Mg atom. Besides, there is no obvious particle aggregation and coke accumulation on the spent-0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1. The good resistance to carbon accumulation may be attributed to the fact that Mg modification reduced the acidic surface sites of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1, which makes it easier for propylene to desorb and avoids the coking phenomenon caused by deep dehydrogenation [26]. Catalytic activity evaluation To investigate the influence of epitaxial S-1 shell, S-1 and DS-1 were used as supports to load active Zn species and the corresponding PDH performance were evaluated. The propylene yield value is also considered as a key indicator for catalyzing dehydrogenation of propane to propylene [27]. As displayed in Fig. 10a , the propylene yield of 5Zn@DS-1was greatly improved (reach to 39%) in comparison to 5Zn@S-1, which can be ascribed to its increased SSA and the confinement effect of double layer. Therefore, DS-1 can be further used as the ideal support for the subsequent preparation of Mg-modified Zn-based catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10b, 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 delivers the initial propylene yield of nearly 38 % and the value maintained at ∼40 % after 6 h, significantly higher than those of 5Zn@DS-1 (20% vs. 36 %). In addition, a significant improvement on the propylene selectivity could be achieved on 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 (Fig. 10c). It is worth noting that the propylene selectivity of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 is almost above 90 %. The propylene selectivity can be stably maintained as the reaction proceeded, which was directly responsible for the improved propylene yield [28]. As shown in Fig. 10d, both of the catalysts show a rapid activity enhancement in the initial 1 h until reaching the steady state. This behavior can be commonly observed in most of alkane dehydrogenation catalysts because abundant active Zn sites are favorable for propane activation and the subsequent propylene desorption. The propane conversion of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 shows a steady plateau ranging from 40 % to 41 %, which also can be attributed to the regulation of Mg species. The influence of Mg modification on the Zn-based catalyst on propylene yield was further investigated by fixing the amount of Zn. Generally, the PDH reaction could reach the catalytic stabilization stage after 2 h. Thus, 2 h of PDH reaction was chosen to evaluate the propylene yields. As shown in Fig. 11 , the propylene yields of the catalysts initially increased and then decreased with the increased Mg content, and it exists an optimal value when Mg/Zn molar ratio was 0.1. The above results indicate the proper Mg modification induces the decreased acidic sites and facilitates the propylene production. Whereas, the excessive Mg may cover the active Zn sites and reduce the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Compared with the previous state-of-the-art PDH catalysts (Table 3 ), the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 exhibits the excellent performance including propylene yield, propylene selectivity, and propane conversion. In terms of the previously reported Mg-modified catalysts, although propylene yield and selectivity can be improved in a certain extent in comparison to some Zn-based catalysts without Mg modification, propane conversion is still to be further enhanced. Thus, the outstanding PDH performance of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 are mainly attributed to the following advantages: (i) Mg modification exerts a significant influence on the Zn species, further determining the surface chemical properties of the catalysts. The improved chemical properties are favorable for the activation of propane and desorption of propylene. (ii) Mg modification contributes to the formation of highly dispersed Zn species due to the dilution role of Mg atom, which effectively relieves the coke accumulation. Thus, the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst can be considered as a potential catalyst for the industrial propane dehydrogenation. Evaluation of stability and regeneration ability In order to evaluate the stability, the long-time stability of the catalyst was investigated by using the space time yield (STY) of propylene as indicator at a higher air velocity. As shown in Fig. 12a , 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 exhibits a higher STY of propylene when compared with 5Zn@DS-1. Also, the STY value of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 decreased only 8 % after the reaction time of 16 h, while 5Zn@DS-1 dramatically decreased, suggesting that the proper Mg-doping improved the stability of the catalyst in PDH reaction. In industrial production, PDH catalysts often need to be frequently regenerated. Thus, it is necessary to investigate the regeneration performance of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1. Specifically, the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 was regenerated three times by calcining in air atmosphere at 550 ℃ for 1 h each time. As shown in Fig. 12b, the propylene yield of the catalyst decreased from ∼44 % to ∼37 % after three times of regenerations, which may be caused by the decreased conversion. However, the propylene selectivity of 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 did not significantly change and could be remained above 90 % (Fig. 12c). The decrease on propylene yield may be due to the aggregation of active Zn species under high temperature reaction and the frequent regeneration leaded to the partially formed ZnO particles, also leading to the decreased conversion (Fig. 12d). However, the steady propylene selectivity still confirms excellent regeneration performance to some extent. Conclusion In this work, we have prepared Mg-modified highly stable Zn-based PDH catalysts by a simple and effective method. The fabricated 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst shows excellent catalytic activity and stability. The propylene selectivity could reach ∼95 % and the propylene yield achieves ∼44 % when modified with a proper amount of Mg. More importantly, the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 also shows good stability. Meanwhile, the cycle regeneration results further confirms the excellent regeneration performance of the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1. This work verifies the 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 can be considered as a potential catalyst for the industrial propane dehydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Zn-based catalysts are considered a kind of efficient catalysts for propane dehydrogenation (PDH) because of their low price and non-toxicity. However, Zn-based catalysts still face problems such as the limited diffusion of reaction gas, non-uniform distribution of Zn species, and easy coking. Here, a novel double-layered silicalite-1 (DS-1) support with high specific surface area was synthesized by a crystal growth method, and an alkaline additive modification strategy has been adopted to prepare the Mg-modified Zn-based catalyst (0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1) in order to improve the catalytic activity and stability. The physical characterization results reveal that the Mg modification induces the enhanced electronic interactions between Zn sites and Mg species. Besides, the modified Mg species also reduce the Lewis acidity, allowing easier desorption of propylene and improving the propylene selectivity with anti-coking property. Furthermore, PDH evaluation results demonstrate that the optimal 0.1Mg5Zn@DS-1 catalyst achieves the propylene yield of ∼44 %, propylene selectivity of ∼95 % as well as outstanding stability and regeneration ability. This work provides a novel insight into the design of Zn-based catalysts with high activity and excellent stability.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of highly stable and efficient Zn-based catalyst via Mg modification for propane dehydrogenation
